definition: to ask for directions/to ask the way (to some place)
lit. to toss a stone to find out what's ahead (idiom)/fig. to test the waters

sentences.english: We can ask for directions at the information desk.
sentences.chinese: 我們可以到問訊處去問路。

sentences.english: He breezed up to the police officer and asked for directions.
sentences.chinese: 他信步走到警官跟前問路。

sentences.english: Man with foreign accents interrupts to ask for information.
sentences.chinese: 一名帶有外國口音的男子在問路。

sentences.english: Don't ask strangers on the street for directions.
sentences.chinese: 也不要在街上隨便找個陌生人問路。

sentences.english: I went up to the policeman and asked directions.
sentences.chinese: 我走到警察跟前向他問路。

sentences.english: A tourist walked up to me to ask the way .
sentences.chinese: 他走到交通警那裏問路。

sentences.english: The gentleman raised the issue very sharp, presumably to testing the waters, right?
sentences.chinese: 呢位阿生提嘅問題好尖銳，大概系想投石問路啩？

sentences.english: Sometimes we just give up and move on.
sentences.chinese: 有時候我們只好打消了問路的念頭繼續趕路。

sentences.english: When I asked the way , I have always received a polite answer.
sentences.chinese: 我問路時，人們總是客客氣氣地回答我。

sentences.english: Certainly, the old woman ask the way excepted.
sentences.chinese: 當然，問路的老太太除外。

sentences.english: I can ask him the way.
A television program of cross century try showed months before the test was thrown stone to detect the road.
sentences.chinese: 早前的一個電視節目“跨世紀的審判”則是投石問路。

sentences.english: There happened to be a policeman around the corner, so I asked him the way.
sentences.chinese: 街角處剛巧有一位警察，我便向他問路。

sentences.english: He breezed up to the policeman and asked for direction.
sentences.chinese: 他輕步走向警察，向他問路。

sentences.english: I've got so many people that I stopped on the streets for directions
sentences.chinese: 在街上，我找了很多人問路。

sentences.english: Ask for and give directions on the street.
sentences.chinese: 在大街上問路和指引方向。

definition: to lead the way/to guide/to show the way/fig. to instruct
to take the car, bus, train etc
to ride (in a vehicle)/to get a lift/to hitch-hike
to get off or out of (a bus, train, car etc)
to hit on someone/to strike up a conversation/to start talking to end an awkward silence or embarrassing situation
to run around all over the place
